paragraph: CHAPTER X. Little Meg as Charwoman
tokens: little

paragraph: Meg and her children did not fail to make their appearance the next morning at Mrs Blossom's shop, where she welcomed them heartily, and made them comfortable again by the kitchen fire.  When they were well warmed, and had finished some bread, and some coffee which had been kept hot for them, Mrs Blossom put on a serious business air.
tokens: child fail make appearance next morning shop welcome make comfortable kitchen fire warm finish bread coffee keep hot put serious business air

paragraph: 'Mr George and me have talked you over,' she said, 'and he's agreed to something.  I can't do my duty by him as I should wish, you know why; and I want a little maid to help me.'
tokens: talk say agree do duty wish know want little maid help

paragraph: 'Oh, if you please,' faltered little Meg, 'I couldn't leave our attic. I promised mother I wouldn't go away till father comes home.  Don't be angry, please.'
tokens: falter little leave attic promise mother go father come angry

paragraph: 'I'm not angry, child,' continued Mrs Blossom.  'I only want a little maid to come mornings, and go away nights, like a char-woman.'
tokens: angry child continue want little maid come morning go night char woman

paragraph: 'Mother used to go charing sometimes,' remarked Meg.
tokens: mother use go chare remark

paragraph: 'I'm not a rich woman,' resumed Mrs Blossom, 'and Mr George has his old father to keep, as lives down in my own village, and I know him well; so we can't give great wages.  I'd give you a half-quartern loaf a day, and Mr George threepence for the present, while it's winter.  Would that suit your views?'
tokens: rich woman resume have old father keep live own village know give great wage give half quartern loaf day threepence present winter suit view

paragraph: 'What could I do with Robbie and baby?' asked Meg, with an air of perplexed thought.
tokens: do ask air perplex thought

paragraph: 'Couldn't you leave 'em with a neighbour?' suggested Mrs Blossom.
tokens: leave neighbour suggest

paragraph: Meg pondered deeply for a while.  Kitty had told her the night before that she had got some sailors' shirts to sew, and would stay at home to make them.  She could trust Robin and the baby with Kitty, and instead of lighting a fire in her own attic she could give her the coals, and so save her fuel, as part payment for taking charge of the children. Yet Meg felt a little sad at the idea of leaving them for so long a time, and seeing so little of them each day, and she knew they would miss her sorely.  But nothing else could be done, and she accepted Mrs Blossom's offer thankfully.
tokens: ponder while tell night get sailor shirt sew stay home make trust baby light fire own attic give coal save fuel part payment take charge child feel little sad idea leave time see little day know miss else do accept offer

paragraph: 'You needn't be here afore nine o' the morning,' said Mrs Blossom; 'it's too early for Posy to be passing by; and you can go away again as soon as it's dark in the evening.  You mustn't get any breakfast, you know, because that's in our bargain; and I'd never grudge you a meal's meat for the children either, bless 'em!  They shall come and have a good tea with us sometimes, they shall--specially on Sundays, when Mr George is at home; and if you'd only got your clothes out o' pawn, we'd all go to church together.  But we'll see, we'll see.'
tokens: morning say early pass go dark evening get breakfast know bargain grudge meal meat child bless come have good tea home get clothes pawn go church see see

paragraph: Meg entered upon her new duties the next morning, after committing the children, with many lingering kisses and last good-byes, into Kitty's charge, who promised faithfully to be as kind to them as Meg herself. If it had not been for her anxiety with regard to them, she would have enjoyed nothing better than being Mrs Blossom's little maid.  The good woman was so kindly and motherly that she won Meg's whole heart; and to see her sit by the shop window, knitting a very large long stocking for Mr George, but with her eyes scanning every woman's face that went by, made her feel full of an intense and childish interest.  She began herself to watch for Posy, as her mother described her; and whenever the form of a grown-up girl darkened the doorway, she held her breath to listen if Mrs Blossom called her by that pet name.  Mr George also was very good to Meg in his bluff way, and bought her a pair of nearly new shoes with his first week's wages, over and above the threepence a day which he paid her.  With Mrs Blossom she held many a conversation about the lost girl, who had grown up wicked, and was therefore worse than dead; and before long Mr George observed that Meg had done her a world of good.
tokens: enter new duty next morning commit child many linger kisse last good by charge promise kind anxiety regard enjoy good little maid good woman motherly win whole heart see sit shop window knitting large long stock eye scan woman face go make feel full intense childish interest begin watch mother describe form grow girl darken doorway hold breath listen call pet name good bluff way buy pair new shoe first week wage threepence day pay hold many conversation lose girl grow wicked bad dead long observe do world good

paragraph: Christmas Day was a great treat to Meg; for though Mr George went down into the country to see his old father, Mrs Blossom invited her and the children to come to dinner, and to stay with her till it was the little ones' bedtime.  When they sat round the fire in the afternoon she told them wonderful stories about the country--of its fields, and gardens, and lanes.
tokens: great treat go country see old father invite child come dinner stay little one bedtime sit fire afternoon tell wonderful story country field garden lane

paragraph: 'I like gardens,' said Robin, 'but I don't like lanes.'
tokens: garden say like lane

paragraph: 'Why don't you like lanes?' asked Mrs Blossom.
tokens: like lane ask

paragraph: 'I know lots of lanes,' he answered.  'There's Rosemary Lane, and it's not nice, nor none of 'em.  They ain't nice like Temple Gardens.'
tokens: know lot lane answer be nice nice

paragraph: 'Rosemary Lane!' repeated Mrs Blossom.  'Why, the lanes in the country are nothing like the lanes in London.  They're beautiful roads, with tall trees growing all along 'em, and meeting one another overhead; and there are roses and honeysuckles all about the hedges, and birds singing, and the sun shining.  Only you don't know anything about roses, and honeysuckles, and birds.'
tokens: repeat lane country lane beautiful road tall tree grow meet be rose honeysuckle hedge bird sing sun shine know rose honeysuckle bird

paragraph: 'Are there any angels there?' asked Robin, fastening his glistening eyes upon her intently.
tokens: be angel ask fasten glisten eye

paragraph: 'Well, no,' said Mrs Blossom, 'not as I know of.'
tokens: say know

paragraph: 'Is the devil in the country?' pursued Robin.
tokens: devil country pursue

paragraph: 'Yes,' answered Mrs Blossom, 'I suppose he's there pretty much the same as here.  Folks can be wicked anywhere, or else my Posy wouldn't have grown up bad.'
tokens: answer suppose same folk wicked grow bad

paragraph: Robin asked no more questions, and Mrs Blossom was glad to talk of something else.  It was a very happy day altogether, but it came too quickly to an end.  Meg wrapped up her children well before turning out into the cold streets, and Mrs Blossom gave them a farewell kiss each, with two to Meg because she was such a comfort to her.
tokens: ask more question glad talk else happy day come end wrap child turn cold street give farewell kiss comfort

paragraph: When they reached their own attic they heard Kitty call to them, and Meg opened her door.  She was sitting without any fire, stitching away as for her life at a coarse striped shirt, lighted only by a small farthing candle; but she laid down her task for a minute, and raised her thin pale face, and her eyes half blinded with tears and hard work.
tokens: reach own attic hear call open door sit fire stitch life coarse stripe shirt light small farthing candle lay task minute raise thin pale face eye half blind tear hard work

paragraph: 'Where have you been all day, little Meg?' she asked.
tokens: day little ask

paragraph: 'Me and the children have been at Mrs Blossom's, answered Meg, 'because it's Christmas Day: and I wish you'd been there as well, Kitty.  We'd such a good dinner and tea.  She gave me a bit of cake to bring home, and you shall have some of it.'
tokens: child answer wish good dinner tea give bit cake bring have

paragraph: 'No, no,' said Kitty, 'it 'ud choke me.'
tokens: say choke

paragraph: 'Oh, it couldn't; it's as nice as nice can be,' said Meg.  'You must just have a taste of it.'
tokens: nice nice say have taste

paragraph: 'Did you go talking about that Posy again?' asked Kitty, bending diligently over her work.
tokens: go talk ask bending work

paragraph: 'We always talk about her,' answered Meg, 'every day.  Mrs Blossom's watching for her to go by all day long, you know.'
tokens: talk answer day watch go day know

paragraph: 'She'll never go by,' said Kitty shortly.
tokens: go say

paragraph: 'Oh, she's certain sure to go by some day,' cried Meg.  'Mrs Blossom asks God to let her go by, every day of her life; and He's positive to do it.'
tokens: certain sure go day cry ask let go day life positive do

paragraph: 'If she's grown up so wicked,' argued Kitty, 'she didn't ought to go back to her mother, and her such a good woman.  God won't send her back to her mother, you'll see.'
tokens: grow wicked argue ought go mother good woman send mother see

paragraph: 'But if God sent her back, her mother 'ud never think of her being wicked, she loves her so,' said little Meg.  'If Robbie were ever so naughty, I'd keep on loving him till he was good again.'
tokens: send mother think wicked love say little naughty keep love good

paragraph: 'Well, Posy'll never go home no more,' said Kitty; and hot tears fell fast upon her work.
tokens: go say hot tear fall work

paragraph: 'She will, she will,' cried Meg.  'I expect her every day, like father. Perhaps they'll both come home to-morrow.  I wish you'd ask God to let Posy and father come home to-morrow.'
tokens: cry expect day father come wish ask let father come

paragraph: 'I'm too bad to ask God for anything,' sobbed Kitty.
tokens: bad ask sobb

paragraph: 'Well, I don't know,' said Meg sorrowfully.  'You're not bad to me or the children.  But I must go to bed now.  Let us kiss you afore we go. Mrs Blossom kissed me twice, and said I was a comfort to her.'
tokens: know say bad child go bed let kiss go kiss say comfort

paragraph: Kitty threw down her work, and clasped Meg strongly in her arms, pressing down Meg's head upon her breast, and crying, 'Oh, my dear little Meg!  My good little Meg!'  Then she put them all three gently out of her room, and bade them good-night and God bless them, in a husky and tremulous voice.
tokens: throw work clasp arm press head breast cry dear little good little put room bid good night bless husky tremulous voice
